reviews.author: Luweegee
reviews.title: Definitely not an easy A course
reviews.comment_content:
Generally a calculus approach to the topics you've learnt in DSE and also some extra stuff (previously in AL). Content load is about DSE Topics 1~3 + Extra Stuff crammed into a semester

===Topics (L = Lecture No.)===
L1: Vectors & 2D Motion
L2~3: Newton's Laws of Motion
L4~5: Kinetic Energy & Potential Energy
L6~7: Momentum & Collisions
--------------QUIZ 1-----------------
L8~10: Dynamics of Rigid Bodies
L11: Angular Momentum
L12~13: Gravitation
L14~15: Periodic Motion
--------------QUIZ 2-----------------
L16~17: Wave Motion & Sound
L18: Temperature & Heat
L19~20: Thermal Properties of Matter
L21~22: 1st and 2nd law of thermodynamics

This course will let you re-learn all the stuff from high-school, but with concepts of calculus. You'll see differentiation (including partial derivatives!!) and integration in formulas, and use of cross products. However, you just need simple algebra when dealing with problems. Calculus is only required in derivation of formulas in class and some questions.

I think this course is quite good and interesting since it teaches some university foundation physics like thermodynamics (You'll see it everywhere). But if your physics is not too good then probably you wanna avoid this as the questions can get frustrating.

I would say this course can be demanding as the content is difficult. If your physics foundation in high school is good, then you should do good :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
===General Teaching===
Generally I don't really like that this course is deduction-themed. All the professors will spend MOST of the time deducing formulas instead of problem-solving, which is equally important. The deduction part is the MOST difficult among the whole course. But trust me, you can do equally well if you can use the formulas correctly without knowing any deductions.

===Professor's Teaching===
Professor Jo's teaching is fine. He talks in a rather soft voice which may be hard to listen. His pronunciation is fine, but can be more clear. I literally took 16 lectures to understand a phrase he used always, which is "F equal ma" =_=. He usually have demonstrations in classes but sometimes they fail to work. You can clear some concepts during class as he'll give extra explanation so it's best to attend all classes

===TA's Teaching in Tutorials===
Yang Shuo (The TA) is literally THE CRAPPIEST TA UST CAN HAVE. He just freaking stands in front of a computer and stares at the screen and teaching NOTHING. Sometimes he'll walk around and stalk behind you. Don't expect to learn anything from him! You need to raise your hand to find him, and sometimes he can't just freaking explain why I did the question wrong.

Also, attendance is recorded so there's no escape :)  I hear that other TAs are fine and they teach you how to solve questions
reviews.comment_grading:
===Grading scheme===
Homework - 10%
Tutorial Attendance - 5%
Test 1 - 20%
Test 2 - 20%
Final Exam - 45%

[Raw scores of the tests will be adjusted according to the relative difficulty of the questions]
===Raw Score Statistics===
Test 1 (First-take): Average - 5.70 ; SD - 2.30
Test 1 (Re-take): Average - 5.89 ; SD - 2.21
Test 2 (First-take): Average - 5.28 ; SD - 2.50
Test 2 (Re-take): Average - 5.23 ; SD - 2.17
Final: Average - 24.1 ; SD - 7.7 ; Range: 6~44

===My scores===
Homework - 10/10
Attendance - 5/5
Test 1 - 9/10 [First take: 9/10 ; Re-take: 8/10] —> 10/10 after adjustments
Test 2 - 10/10 [First take: 10/10]
Final - 38/45
-------
Final score: 93%
Grade: A+

===Tests (20% x 2)===
Tests are held regularly and non-cumulative. You sit in front of a computer to complete 10 questions for 1 hour. Most of them require you to input a number for answer, and there are around 2~3 MCs. Usually there are 1~2 challenging question that takes you quite some time. Be sure to check for any silly mistakes!
Re-take policy - Highest score is recorded from one of following:
1. First take
2. Average of first and second take
3. Second take * 80%

===Final (45%)===
45 MC questions and CLOSED BOOK. (Have formula sheet provided) It mainly covers the content not covered in tests 1 and 2. Around 40% of questions are related to thermodynamics and gases (L18~22), and they are DIFFICULT. There are 2 questions that require you to derive equations (one using calculus). The professors claimed that they will have 25% questions each for L1~13, L14~17, L18~20 and L21~22 respectively, but there are some deviations from the final paper.

===Homework (10%)===
You are forced to buy a textbook to obtain licensing key for online homework system "MasteringPhysics". You need to complete around 6~10 questions EACH WEEK for the topics just have been taught. (Except for the test weeks, they are not graded). I think they will round off your score to 10/10 if you score 9X% in total for your homework. (Someone says your MasteringPhysics score is multiplied 110% to become your final homework score)

===Tutorials (5%)===
Just show up on time and answer a PRS question. You can leave right after checking attendance (if your TA is shitty lol)


I think you need to be hard-working to get good grade (especially do a lot of questions and recite how to approach that question). If you do slightly above mean I think you get B- or B (not really sure)

By the way, there's a policy to ban any Mainland students from enrolling this in FALL semester only. So, I think the mean in fall semester is a bit lower.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload. Can get a little bit more demanding if your physics base knowledge is not good enough. The workload mostly come from doing homework and revising for tests and exams (which were held per 3~4 weeks).

===Homework===
Doing MasteringPhysics is ABSOLUTELY FRUSTRATING. They deduct 10% mark for every incorrect answer. Sometimes they deduct you marks for something stupid like missing minus sign or slightly off number. The questions are also quite difficult and you need to copy the whole stupid question to Google to find answers. You got to repeat this torture each week :)

reviews.author: couch_potato
reviews.title: Your effort will pay off in this course, do put effort into it

Quite excellent course planning for an introductory physics course. Skipped fluid mechanics, but it will be introduced in future PHYS/MECH/CIVL courses.

TBC
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor is very passionate in his teaching, such that even though he appears to be in a sickly state for the semester, he is still very willing to provide extra lectures and review sessions.
The lessons are mostly proving of formulas, which I find very useful in helping to understand the conditions and the meaning behind the formulas. This particular lecturer often has different methods for proving the formulas than the lecture notes, so you can learn from different ways.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% Tutorial Attendance
10% Mastering Physics HW
20% each test, 2 tests in total, varying difficulty
45% Final, 45MCQ, all difficult

For me, full attendance, HW full marks
Test 1 8/10
Retest 1 9/10
Test 2 9/10
Retest 9/10
Final 38/45
Overall grade: A

2 of my friends with Final 38/45 but slightly better performances in the 2 tests both got A+
It was kinda infuriating for me, but I have to say the cut off is fair

reviews.comment_teaching:
To be honest, the professor's pronunciation wasn't clear enough for international students to understand.

I've attended the lecture less than 10 times due to such reasons. However, attending to lecture isn't that important for this course. However, you MUST attend the tutorial sessions. It counts for your grade.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading really depends on how much you try. Questions in tests are definitely harder than those you get from the mastering physics questions. However, those questions you see in mastering physics are very helpful and will be a good resource when you prepare for the tests or for the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is one of the courses that have heavy workloads.

You have to complete mandatory Mastering Physics homework every week. Each assignment is due 11:59 pm of every Sunday.

In order to complete Mastering Physics assignments, you have to buy the textbook: University Physics 14th edition and get a code for mastering physics.

Completing assignments every week will be very burdensome and tired after all. Still, it is important to know question types before you take any tests.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
This course talks about DSE mechanics with calculus (eg integration, differentiation), plus angular momentum, simple harmonic motion, and thermodynamics.

You have to buy a book called Mastering Physics, so that you can have a valid account to do the homework. 2nd-hand books carry invalid accounts.

During class, you will be taught theories or the proofs of those theories. Only in tutorial class can you learn how to apply the knowledge and do the questions. Even so, you are not advised to skip lectures as in the final exam (45 MC, 3 hrs) questions are not similar to those you encountered. Only concepts are related, but not the types of questions, I would say. So, understanding and remembering the fundamental concepts or theories may be very important.
reviews.comment_teaching: There may be some experiments during lectures, but just a few. You may find it sleepy looking at the white board full of mathematical proofs in the early class, just like me.
reviews.comment_grading:
For details and data, lease refer to the attached file.

For the final exam, which is entirely MC questions, you have to make sure that you spend every minute carefully. Calculations may need you more than 5 minutes so that you can ensure your first step is correct. Plus, to the nest of my knowledge, those mechanics problems were mostly akin to those in AL physics.

In addition, prior to the final exam, only one past paper will be uploaded to canvas. You had better do it seriously and try to change the question after finishing so as to ensure you can cope with questions with the same topic but different situations. I remembered that in the last lecture the lecturer attempted to explain how to do each question but he failed to do some of them.
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty high. You have to do one piece of homework once a week through Mastering Physics online platform. Although some of the questions and their corresponding answers may be found online, answers from the web may not be always true, and wrong answering will cause mark deduction.

For those who aim a high grade but have not yet done AL physics MC (mechanics) before, it may be pretty demanding for you as you had better try them as soon as possible so as to get adapted to the way of thinking.

On the other side, there are lecture videos from L4 upload and the lecturer, Leung Pak Wo, teaches better as he explain things in a much simpler way, which is easier to understand

I am not the only one since some local students who have not studied Physics in HKDSE need to fulfil the major requirement by passing this course.

Topics:
Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D - projectile
Newton's laws of motion
Work and kinetic energy
Potential energy and energy conservation
Momentum, impulse and collision
Dynamics of rigid bodies
Angular momentum
Gravitation
Periodic motion
Wave motion and sound
Temperature and heat
Thermal properties of matter
First law of Thermodynamics

reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Cheung can explain clearly. It will be better to attend the lectures, otherwise, it may be difficult to understand the concepts from a mere note.

For tutorials, Mr. Ko is also good at explaining abstract concepts.

However, since they may assume most of the students have Physics background, students like me may not catch up what they are saying.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme: (*Maybe changed next year)
Assignments 5%
Tutorials 5%
Test 1 20%
Test 2 20%
Final Exam 50%

My grade: C
Assignment: 4.72/5
Test 1: 1.77/10 (1st take 0, retake 2)
Test 2: 4.23/10 (1st take 4, retake 1)
Tutorial participation: 14.5/16 (I was late for several classes)
Final: 13/45 (I have only studied Thermodynamics)

I got a C. For a person who doesn't have any Physics background and doesn't put much effort in this course and fail in every test, this grade is really, really good.
As long as you have finished your homework and attend every tutorial, you won't fail this course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite heavy. You have to finish around 9 questions in Mastering Physics every week as homework. You only have 6 trials. Each trial deducts 3% marks. You also need to attend tutorials every week. You also have 2 quizzes so it's better to revise after each lecture.

reviews.author: Jacky 01
reviews.comment_content: At the beginning the content is mainly focused on newton mechanic which we learnt in secondary school, such as projectile motion, circular motion and momentum. However after the first test most of the content is new, such as angular momentum, periodic motion, wave motion and thermal dynamic. It is quite hard to understand so I suggest you should do revision every week. The tutorial will count attendance as it will hold 5% of the total marks. You will do about 2 basic exercise to clear you concept and 1 to 2 content based question which is harder. You will do it in groups. In order to gain the 5% marks you don't need to get the answer correctly. You just need to show some writing on the exercise.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung is quite good. He will make some joke and show some experiments during lecture. He will also use hand written notes to explain the concept.
reviews.comment_grading:
There will be 10 assignments, 2 test, 2 re-test and a final exam
5% homework
5% tutorial
20% test 1
20% test 2
50% final exam
Test 1 & 2 were done with a computer online. The question is different to every student, so as the difficulties. The more difficult the question is, the more marks you gonna get. Each test has 10 question which consist of MC and fill in the blank. Retest is optional. there will be 3 ways to count your test marks:
1. The first take only
2. 80% of the retest marks
3. Average marks of the first take and retest
the final test score will be adjusted  depends on the difficulties after the final exam.
The final exam consist of 45 MC, it mainly focus on the content which is not covered in the first 2 test.

My score is:
test 1: 7/10
test 1 retake: 7/10
test final score : 7.37/10
test 2: 6/10
test 2 retake: 10/10
test 2 final score : 8.12/10
final exam 24/45
HW & tutorial full marks
Grading: B
I didn't have enough time to do revision during the final exam as I need to do revision for the math 1014. But I think because I performed well in the two test so I can still get a B. Test 1 & 2 are much easier than final exam, so I suggest you to try to perform well in the test and always do the re-test if you don't get full marks.
reviews.comment_workload: I think it is quite high as you have homework every week and you need to do revision every weeks. The final exam covers the entire topic and it is quite hard. So you need to work hard. And somehow the phys final exam is always followed by math final exam during the fall and spring semester, so there are not a lot of time to do revision.

reviews.comment_teaching:
PROF 會係堂上推導D THEORY 出黎,對於對物理有興趣既CHING 係唔錯既, 但係對做題方面就冇咩幫助。

Mastering physics 同 textbook 既題目救世界, 想好GRADE一定要做。(yahoo 知識比 tutorial 更值得花時間)

至於tutorial 係唔計attendance,而去定唔去, 當然係去得到先好去, 但如果唔明d題目點做,急住要問, help desk 既時間就要緊記啦。
reviews.comment_grading:
算係好GRADE
1st test 7/10
2nd test 7/10
final 大概60%

ABOVE MEAN 有B+

努力同成果會成正比既
reviews.comment_workload:
一星期一份MASTERING PHYSICS assignment , Workload 多少就見人見智,要遇一星期可以有1個鐘時間做就OK。

但係想好GRADE 唔太建議只係做assignment, 個Course 會比D supplementary exercise(都係mastering physic入面) , 雖然WORKLOAD 會比較大, 但係值得既, 因為好多midterm , final 題目同入面既類形相似。

reviews.author: Derek Hong
reviews.comment_content:
DSE PHYSICS + Rigid body with CALCULUS EXPRESSION
Topics included:
Classical Mechanics
Physical Quantities, Vectors, and 2D Motion
Newton's Laws of Motion
Work and Kinetic Energy
Potential Energy and Energy Conservation
Momentum, Impulse, and Collisions
Dynamics of Rigid Bodies
Angular Momentum
Gravitation
Simple Harmonic Motion
reviews.comment_teaching:
I skipped all the classes after week 3 so i don't know is he good or not. I think lecture is useless for studying. Tutorial is fine if you have question already before the class.
Some of my friends said cheung man fung's lecture is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
All mean score and get b-.
I think it's okay in HKUST.
No any score adjust in this semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only mastering physics need. You can search the answer on google.
Be careful when you submit the answer, you only have 3chances. No marks for any typo. If you get ~90% You can get all the credit
Turtorial required for every week, class work will counted to final grade. No pain no gain in this course. If you work hard, you can get a good result.

reviews.author: Peterleung
reviews.comment_content:
上半part基本上全部都係高中嘢, force and motion嗰啲, 中學有聽書應該冇乜問題
之後就會有wave, gas law, heat嗰啲, 會有啲難
大部分chapter嘅數都會涉及calculus, 但test同final都唔係考好多calculus
test同final都有formula sheet, 但有2成嘅式要自己記

2個test, final全部MC
reviews.comment_teaching:
教得好清晰, 上堂主要係由頭prove番d式出黎, 明左d式之後就冇乜難度
不過都係跟lec notes教, 有信心嘅都可以走堂, 自己刨notes

tutorial係幫你清concept嘅, 如果你唔係好明lecture嘅話就更加要去
本身physics同數底好嘅話tutorial其實幾無聊, tutorial d題目同final又唔太似

reviews.author: ywloab
reviews.comment_content:
1.Motions and Newton's laws
2.Work and energy
3.Conservation of energy and momentum
4.Rotational motion
5.Rigid body
6.Simple harmonic and damped oscillations

reviews.comment_teaching: His English is clear
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz1: 7/10 Mean 5.5/10
Quiz2:7/10 Mean 4.7/10
Final: 27/45 Mean 22/45
Turn out B+
Remember to do sample paper if you want to get a good grade
(I forgot to do...)
For final exam, I recommend you finish the questions of wave or heat first.
Mechanic questions are much harder.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy as you need to hang in assignment on the internet (mastering physics) every week.
around 10 questions per week
Some questions are difficult.

reviews.author: donwadeeho
reviews.title: One of the good grade course
reviews.comment_content: Most of the content are DSE physics level, if you got good grades in DSE physics then it should not be a big problem for you to get above mean.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are not quite useful. However if you participate more in tutorials, you can gain from it since it is practical exercise and they have us divided in groups.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. Mean is around B-.
reviews.comment_workload: Online HW every week. Don't forget to set reminder for yourself as finals/mid term period usually makes you totally forget about the HW.

reviews.author: 雲追夢
reviews.title: 一分辛勞一份收穫的課程
reviews.comment_content:
Test 1 基本DSE，
Test 2 Rotation，不溫書的話基本放棄，
Final 必須溫熱，做好心理準備不容易。
reviews.comment_teaching:
梁伯和與張文峰上課有趣生動，
可是基本不必上課，
自己努力刨notes更好。
reviews.comment_grading:
一分錢一分貨，fair吧
如果不給努力，基本上會讓你很失望。
reviews.comment_workload:
如果aim A range是有workload 的，
主要功夫花在理解上面，
想明白了就融會貫通了，
A range 是不難的。
還有記住交功課，那是唯一可以100%的項目，可是有10%佔比的。
有缺勤記錄的就要去上tutor了，有缺勤的通常比較好grade。

reviews.author: 阿輝
reviews.title: difficult course
reviews.comment_content:
呢科本身內容好難,如果無學過PHYSICS真係好難catch up到,因為佢assume你已經識好多野,一黎就入正題,所以佢要你phy有3 或者讀過1001先比你reg.
但我覺得phy只係得3既人入到黎呢科只會係差唔多最低層,因為再重申多次呢科既內容真係好難。
建議擺多啲時間落去,要上足哂lecture同tutorial,就會跟到。
reviews.comment_teaching:
cheung man fung係一個好老師
講完
reviews.comment_grading:
我自己就b range.
個陣mastering physics 10%(拎哂)
兩個quiz 20%一個
10條mc, 計番即係成2%一條
我兩個quiz都係岩左一半, 當我拎左20%
final 50%, 40條mc, 5條bonus (即係你拎45條滿分都係40)
我final 23/40

quiz同final都below mean
但可能分唔算低
最後都有b
reviews.comment_workload:
workload唔大呀,得mastering phy要上網做
大部份時間都係靠自己溫書
好重要,一定要上完一堂就溫
唔係既話你miss一堂野你即gg 我話既

reviews.author: Jack Tang
reviews.comment_content: 其實cover左好多中學嘢，如果中學有讀過phy而且有5以上應該好易明啲嘢，所以應該唔算難
reviews.comment_teaching: 上堂有啲悶，prof凈係識對住自己份筆記講，然後抄啲嘢落whiteboard
reviews.comment_grading: 算好grade，幾次test都近mean或者below少少，但最後都有B
reviews.comment_workload: 個個禮拜都要做mastering physics，但係都得幾題，workload正常

reviews.author: HKo
reviews.comment_content:
1. PHYSICAL QUANTITIES, VECTORS AND 2D MOTION
2. NEWTON’S LAWS OF MOTION
3. WORK AND KINETIC ENERGY
4. POTENTIAL ENERGY & ENERGY CONSERVATION
5. MOMENTUM, IMPULSE, AND COLLISIONS
6. DYNAMICS OF RIGID BODIES
7. ANGULAR MOMENTUM
8. GRAVITATION
9. PERIODIC MOTION
10. WAVE MOTION AND SOUND
11. TEMPERATURE AND HEAT
12. THERMAL PROPERTIES OF MATTER
13. FIRST LAW OF THERMODYNAMICS
14. SECOND LAW OF THERMODYNAMICS

Things before "dynamics of rigid bodies" are covered in high school, so it is not hard to get started with this course. However, some content after "dynamics of rigid bodies" are deeper than that in high school; one'd better study hard to make sense of those content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teacher is knowledgeable and usually asks questions during the class. However, when no one answers the questions, it results in an embarrassing situation, and the lecture stops progressing.
Sometimes the lecture is boring because it's easy; whereas sometimes it's hard to catch up with the professor since you're not familiar with the topic.
I recommend studying with the textbook to fully understand the content.
**The professor's words is not big, so you'd better sit as front as possible.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: full mark(it's relative)
Test1: 10/10
Test2: 10/10
Final Exam: 33/45
Finally got an A.

The final exam is quite harder than both tests.
There are helping desks during the study break, it's recommended to finish the past final paper during that period, and have your questions solved.
I finished the past final paper a day before the final exam. I had a lot of questions to ask then, but unable to figure out all of them within the short time. It turned out that some of those questions appeared again in the final exam, and I didn't get those marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework every week, around 8~10 problems.
You can find some similar questions in the textbook.
Some problems are designed badly; you need to write email to check with the professor. Sometimes the questions might turn out to be no marks, after you spent a lot of time on them.

reviews.author: jeffreyheihei
reviews.title: not a difficult course
reviews.comment_content: knowledge based on DSE physics and calculus, not difficult. quite a lot of topic, one or two lessons will teach one topic.
reviews.comment_teaching:
overall is ok, but sometimes it is boring and sleepy, maybe because i
take the morning session. with some experiment, sit front if you want to watch the experiment. no attendance will be taken in lecture. but some session will take attendance for the tutorial, my session does not take attendance, so I skip it all, but you can download the tutorial material with the answers in canvas. you can ask the TA if you do not understand the topic and question, if you can finish the tutorial material yourself, just skip it.
many people will ask question after the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: quite easy to get a B, but hard to get  A or above, final is much more difficult than two test
reviews.comment_workload: only mastering physics about once a week. need to study before two test and final. should study early before final, it is not a good idea to study final two days before if you are not genius.

reviews.author: Shirayuki
reviews.comment_content:
Some Force and motion, wave and heat from Dse but with deeper and different approach. Not to difficult to catch up but need some time to deal with it.
There are also some new ideas but they appear at the end of the semester and not included in Final as long as I remember.
If you are from DSE physics, you should able to catch up in class
reviews.comment_teaching: Following the lecture notes, with more explanations. It is fun to attempt classes. With some experiment in class, you may understand more. Even he proves the equations in class, you don't have to remember them, none of them will appear in Mastering Physics quiz or final. Also, you may ask him questions after class, he will kindly explain to you.
reviews.comment_grading: Mean = C
reviews.comment_workload:
Mastering Physics per week
Two quizzes
One Final Exam

Every week a Mastering Physics webwork, sometimes they may find some question failed and not count it. There are lots of sources online.
two quizzes instead of midterm, not too difficult, a little easier than Exam. If you did not do well in the first time, you can have a second try.
Final is all MC this sem.

reviews.author: Nosna
reviews.comment_content:
主要都係教返同DSE physic差唔多嘅野
Force同motion會加埋inertia同rigid body嘅concept
Heat就會加埋少少thermodynamics嘅野,例如first law, second law, adiabatic process, Carnot engine等等

雖然個course話要用到calculus嘅野, 不過其實都係D好簡單嘅differentiation同integration, 同埋會用少少partial differentiation

成個course最主要都係要識用D formula
Test1,2會cover係force同motion嘅野, 10條short question, 入面有一兩條mc, 之後其他都係唔同嘅case 問你個force/workdone/velocity係咩, 用電腦做.
Exam會係45條mc,其中5條bonus. Cover曬成個course嘅野, 主要係問後期教heat嘅野, 有十幾題會問force motion嘅野 叫你prove返條式出黎.
reviews.comment_teaching: Chen Tian Wen係教得幾好既lecturer, 好多formula都會慢慢prove比你. Tutorial一定要上, lecture好多時都冇example question比你, tutorial個tutor會教你點樣係條問題推個答案出黎同埋教你點用D formula
reviews.comment_grading:
Test1: 9/10 mean: 6.3
Test2: 8/10 mean: 6
Exam 35/40 mean: 21
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: 每個星期要做online homework, 7-10條question, D問題都有D難, 不過google下都會揾到answer

reviews.author: Sasha Yang
reviews.comment_content: Not that hard, similar to AP physics as far as I know. Topics include force and motion, as well as waves and thermodynamics, while equations used are not that different from those used in high school.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not particularly interesting, and may be a bit hard to grasp. The professor tried to make the lessons more interesting by being interactive and asking questions, which is great for students to revise some basic concepts of the topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is 5% attendance for tutorials, 5% for assignments, 20% for each of the 2 tests, and 50% for final exam.

There are retakes allowed for the tests, so even if your mark for the first take is unsatisfactory, there is still a chance to get better scores. Scores for the tests are also known immediately, so students would not have to wait for their results.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fair. I was able to familiarize myself with the homework and quizzes, but it was not too much that I would feel burdened. The tutorials however, could be more useful in being more focused on each student's misunderstandings rather than being vague about what students should do in the practices.

reviews.author: biochemnerd
reviews.title: Avoid it if you can! This course gave me PTSD for physics
reviews.comment_content: just read other reviews lah~ its "basic" stuff like newton's laws, kepler's laws, forces, angular momentum, torque, parallel axis theorem and all blah blah blah
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Sheng teaches in a simple, straight-forward manner which I personally appreciate from professors teaching such tough courses. His accent can be a bit difficult sometimes, but overall he spends time to clearly give examples to explain concepts. He spends time to focus on more important details than scare us with the math.
Compared to other prof I took this course with earlier (Choy Ting Pong), he is a lot more sorted and experienced with teaching. Prof Choy teaches well, but he emphasized a lot on the mathematical reasonings behind the physics, which does not benefit students who do not like math as much.
reviews.comment_grading: Its all based on mean and sd like other courses. Just see other reviews for this, they've mentioned it again probably.
reviews.comment_workload:
Mastering physics is a royal pain to finish, the questions are confusing and long. But it is a good practice for final exam.
Tutorials are usless to go to, as the questions there are not relevant AT ALL to the exam content or type of questions. My lecture (L3, or usually L4-L6 for students taking it in Fall) had tutorial graded so I guess it makes a random 5% boost to your overall mark.
Test I and II is more like mastering physics, so I recommend doing homework (even though its a pain)
Lectures help, but if books are better source for you then it also works.

reviews.author: yusless
reviews.comment_content:
Roughly half of the DSE covered topics will be taught in this course.

More difficult than DSE in my opinion.

In order to do well on exams and quizzes, you will need to do lots of exercises (provided by MasteringPhysics, an online platform where you get the access code by purchasing the textbook). To be honest, I have not used the textbook at all in my learning, so it may be up to you. But I felt that the notes can give you sufficient points to learn the basic concepts of the course.

In order to make sure your understanding is actually correct, I think the homework has to be done. MasteringPhysics will also provide extra questions later on in the course to allow you more questions for self practice, and they do NOT count towards your course grading.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good course instructor, enthusiastic. Worth going to the lectures, especially since there will be no lecture videos provided.

Tutor was alright, but I think the tutorials are just to consolidate your knowledge learnt from lectures. You must attend tutorials for the attendance marks, which are obtained by doing the in-tutorial tasks.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes can be quite difficult. I failed my two first-take quizzes, in fact. But due to the retaking mechanic introduced in the course, I was able to attain a score above the mean in the retakes of the quizzes.

However, I suggest that you study hard for the first-take of the quiz as it is the most advantageous way to obtain good grades for this course if you do well in them.

The exams are MC-based. Not easy at all compared to the homework you get. You need to obtain at least 3X out of 45 MCs to obtain a grade above B as far as I know.
reviews.comment_workload: It's okay if you have a good physics background as it really is similar to the DSE syllabus. However, I recommend you to revise often to have a good understanding of the course in general and do the homework weekly on time as well, especially if your math and physics background isn't up to par.

reviews.author: So far so good
reviews.title: A review of DSE Physics
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the content are taught in DSE physics, but with some new equations like wave equation, and new topics like thermodynamics.
Spend a reasonable time would be easy to follow up for those of the new things added.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teach normally, you will still learn something by attending to his lectures, some of the content/his point of view about the teaching stuff that are not included in the notes, which might help you to have better understanding of the topics.
The notes are just extracted from the text book but simplified. For me, it lacks of a lot details inside, so reading textbook is a much better option for me, however, it does consume more time to build up your own point of view.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fairly graded.
Two midterm with 20% each and one final 40%, homework also counts for 10%.
My result:
Midterm 1: 10/10 mean: 5.56 SD: 2.44
Midterm 2: 10/10 mean: 5.18 SD: 2.59
Final: 32/45 mean: 21.8 SD: 7.8
It Turns out grade A

Final is much harder then midterm, remember it.
Practice of using calculus to solve certain problem is requred, do all homework and practice problem under Mastering Physics would be helpful.
reviews.comment_workload: Not quite a burden, one homework per week, it is the basic, so surely you should take more problems by yourself to get better grade.

reviews.author: lai19190
reviews.comment_content: In the first half of the content(Force and Motion), it's just adding new concept on the fundamental physics you learned in secondary school.For another half(wave, heat), it is completely new for students and i think it's the hardest part in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
his lessons is very interesting and his English is understandable.
He spends lots of time in prove and it does help you to understand the theorem.
reviews.comment_grading:
grade is fair
got 8/10 in both test
final: 25/45 (mean:21.8 sd=7.8)
finally i got a B+
reviews.comment_workload: every week, you will need to complete about 8 questions on mastering physics and every wrong answer will cost you 3% of the question scores.For me, it is quite heavy to do it weekly.

reviews.author: edwardo
reviews.title: for people are good at physics or just hope to have a C+ /B
reviews.comment_content: the content is quite similar to HKDSE standard with some more detail about mathematics behind and the proving of it . It is not hard for people who good at both maths and physic , (IE, if you are good at MATHS1013&1014 then you should be totally fine with most of the content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
If you are having lessons with this instructor , you are luck.His teaching is comparatively less boring and most importantly, his English is understandable.
however, the tutorial section is kind of useless so i suggest you skip those if you will revise at home / hall
***For some of the tutorial , (actually only 1 tutor) require student to take attendance every lesson which will contribute 5% to your total marks.so skip tutorials at your own risk .
reviews.comment_grading:
normal grading , mean have about C+ to B
work harder in both of the midterms , as the finals in considered as "insanely hard "for most of the students.
Your final grade will be mostly controlled by webworks and midterms.
reviews.comment_workload:
every week you will have a webwork which requires your passcode on the textbook to log-in
No extra homework if you don`t attend tutorials

reviews.author: Wtfclintonli
reviews.title: Reasonable Difficulty (Not during exam!)
reviews.comment_content: The content of the a bit too difficult for students obtained a 4 in DSE as in the first half of the content may cover a slightly advance version of Force and motion. However, for the second half of the content, the material is mostly new to the majority of the student.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching of Altman is really good, he can make the class less boring compare to other class. The tutorial is also good for you as it will guide you through question you may or may not encounter before. You can learn the basics of the material through lecture and understand the principle of the questions and problems thorough the tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading: The content of the exam is not really related to the class material, it is more complicated and much more difficult than the homework, luckily the mean of tests and the exam are not too high.
reviews.comment_workload: There are homework once per week, and two mid-term exam. You need to revise to obtain a B-range grade, but the hw and the tutorial can help you on that. You need to definitely spend time on the homework.

reviews.comment_content:
Motions and Newton's laws

Cheung Man Fung hold 堂，質素保證！

chur

reviews.author: Nikhil
reviews.comment_content:
Content after test1 kept getting more and more difficult.
Syllabus:
Motions and Newton's laws
Work and energy
Conservation of energy and momentum
Rotation
Rigid body
Simple harmonic and damped oscillations
Forced oscillations

reviews.comment_teaching: OUTSTANDING!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment(HW): 10%
Test 1: 20% (Not all MCQ's)
Test 2: 20% (Not all MCQ's)
Final: 50% (All MCQ's)
The online exercices as well as the weekly assignments will help a lot.
Do not miss the TUTORIALS!
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly graded online assignment can get a bit annoying. However, they indirectly prepare you for test1 and test2.

reviews.author: BUBUBU
reviews.title: The more you put the more u gain
reviews.comment_content: The materials before mid-term are generally covered in DSE curriculum. But you need to expect that would be more mathematical and deep. After the mid-term, the difficulty will surge exponentially and it also includes most of the challenging concept,
reviews.comment_teaching: He is a passionate professor who is eager to provide help and assistance to your question. But sometimes, he cannot provide a clear explanation on some of the concept and question, and some of the steps are not explicitly stated.
reviews.comment_grading: If you need to get a good grade in this course, you should be very diligent and eager to do exercise. Since this course is also taken by a lot of elite from all around the world who may already be acknowledged some of the concepts taught in this course. So, in such a fierce competitive conditions, getting A is more difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Online assignment almost every week. midterms and finals as usual. They also have some of the questions in tutorial notes.

reviews.author: Wendyyy
reviews.title: lovely course
reviews.comment_content:
Newton’s Laws, work and energy, conservation of energy and momentum, rotation, rigid body, simple harmonic and damped oscillations, forced oscillations, standing waves and sound waves, kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics.

don't need to know much about calculus.

This course sustained my love for physics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
My class is mainly taught by Prof. Altman. I think he is OK. The lectures can get a bit boring sometimes as his teaching pace is very slow and he had made mistakes in his notes which confused me.

Prof. Chen's teaching pace is very fast but he is able to explain things clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good Grade.
my scores:
HW 100/100
All tests (both 1st take and retake) 9/10
Final 35/45
my grade: A
could have gotten an A+ given my physics knowledge but it's still nice when you can get an A easily.
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is acceptable, only one online HW consisting of 8-10 questions per week.
there are tutorial sessions which do not take attendance.

reviews.author: Jacky C
reviews.title: it is easy if you work hard
reviews.comment_content: before midterm, it is same as the physics in HKDSE. after midterm, it will teaching some new field, such as angular mechanics and heat efficiency.
reviews.comment_teaching: it is interesting and it will show some experiment in calss. leung pak woo's course are morefocus on how to apply the knowledge. cheung man fung's course are more focus on how the equation come and its meaning. i suggest u to go both course to achieve better grade.
reviews.comment_grading:
the first quiz is all about the DSE physics, read your secondary phys note
the second quiz is about things base on Dse phys.
final is all MC good luck
reviews.comment_workload:
it does not have too much homework, but 2 quiz which equal to the midterms.
it also have a tutorial which count attendance

reviews.author: gotoschoolbybus
reviews.title: 其實好難
reviews.comment_content:
test 1 之前 都係教番D 普通DSE force and motion 之後就開始加好多 calculus落去
利申: DSE PHY得4 M2得5
自己讀落去就覺得好難好辛苦 有D概念好複雜 同埋佢有D位係要有partial differentiation D 野係入面 所以就真係唔好睇小佢地
去到最面仲有wave 周埋Thermodynamics 個人覺得好好好難明 特別係Thermodynamics 真係唔知佢做緊D咩
所以內容其實好複雜,係的確有D難明,係要自己再吸收下

上左一個月堂之後就冇上

但係上Tutorial有用好多
可以識番D野
reviews.comment_grading:

Test 1: 4/10
test 2: 3/10  re test 2:3/10
Final 13/45

reviews.comment_teaching:
Don't know about the lectures, cause I did not attend any class.

However, the tutorials are crap, they don't teach anything. They only upload a worksheet with a few questions on Canvas, and you are suppose to do the worksheet at home, if you come across any difficulty, then come to the tutorial to ask the TA. Otherwise, don't bother to go.
reviews.comment_grading:
Test 1 20%
Test 2 20%
Final 50%
Homework 10%

*There are re-test for test 1 and 2

You can only get away in test 1 with a good DSE physics background. Starting from test 2, you better start studying, or else you will regret it.
The final was mainly about the chapters which were not covered in test 1 and 2. However, the mechanics problems were hard.

Always remember to be careful when taking the test, they are not hard. Each incorrect answer = 1-2% (depending if you take the re-rest or not) of the overall course marks. I suffered a lot from this.

The grading in this semester was not as good as before, at least that is what I feel. People said that this course was giving out around 20% A range, yet I got around 1SD above mean in each test and exam, having the same score with someone last year in this website, and ended up having a B+, which that guy ended up having an A-. Though with that being said, the grading is still fair.

For your reference:
Test 1: 8/10 Mean: 5.56 SD: 2.44
Test 2: 8/10 Mean: 5.18 SD: 2.59
Final: 29/45 Mean: 21.8 SD: 7.8
reviews.comment_workload:
Depending if you like physics or not, for me I did enjoy the course through out. If you don't like physics and is forced to study this, well you will be having a rough time.

There will be around 10 questions given each week through Mastering Physics, which it quite time consuming to finish.

Remember time invested = grade in this subject.

If you want better grades, you need to solve to problems in the book, and do the extra exercises given in Mastering Physics.

For anyone of you ask me, why did I do so much and yet, just manage to obtain only 29/45 in the final? Well, it is because I got 4 finals packed together during that period, and the content in this subject is huge! So...... I didn't do any revision for the last 2 chapters, and relied on spinning my eraser instead.

reviews.author: Otaku
reviews.title: Excellent introductory course
reviews.comment_content:
This course is available to students with adequate background in physics and basic calculus in high school. As such, the content would be a little more challenging than its non-calculus based counterpart, phys1111.

The structure of this course is well-designed. The first few lectures enabled students to warm up and relearn concepts we should have learnt in high school. After that, the pace became considerably faster as it introduces new concepts such as rigid bodies mechanices, SHM, wave motions, and thermodynamices, none of which is covered in the HKDSE physics curriculum. Despite its fast pacing, the explanations provided by the instructor and the note is clear and one only needs to take his/her time to fully digest it after lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor has a easily-understandable Chinese accent, though it could be a bit strange at times. He seldom follows the lecture notes. Instead, he tends to derive the necessary and important results with his own methods, which in my opinion is more elegant and easier to understand. According to him, our class actually got the highest mean in both Test 1 and Test 2, so that should be a testimony of how good his teaching is.
reviews.comment_grading: Very lenient. The average performance is not very outstanding, therefore strong students could be differentiated easily.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course could be potentially huge when it comes to the weekly Mastering Physics online assignments if one doesn't understand what has been taught that week. However, one can always contact the instructor and the TA of your tutorial session to seek help. One can also just copy the whole question and google it to find solutions available online. Other than that, the workload should be light as one only has to study for test 1, 2, as well as the the final examination, which has the heaviest weighting in score calculation.

reviews.author: ylh
reviews.comment_content:
The course is pretty similar to the DSE physics but it's a harder version with some m2 stuff. (e.g. integration, vectors) It cover 3 main topics in 24 lectures, which are:

-Force and Motion
circular motion, newton's laws, rotation, angular momentum, gravitation

-Wave Motion
SHM, sound waves

-Thermodynamics (Heat)
Laws of thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching:
Terrible.
The professor is a foreigner and his accent is okay. But he is just speaking out the words from the slides without much elaboration. The teaching is one-sided and boring af. Basically the only advantage of attending the lecture is it gives you a chance for power napping. You can't learn anything from the lesson and almost half of the class disappeared after mid september lol. The tutor is a local teaching assistant and he teaches much better than the professor. No comment for the tutor as I only attended the first tutorial lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Assignment
20% Test 1
20% Test 2
50% Final Exam

The 10% Assignment is completing MasteringPhysics. There will be 10 assignments in total, one per week. Your mark will be rounded up to 100% automatically if you got more than 90% in one assignment. However, you are searching for the answer in yahoo at most of the time instead of doing it by yourself since it is pretty difficult. Note that you have to purchase the physics textbook in order to get this 10% mark, which costs you 300$ wtf.

Both tests consist of 10 questions, one mark each, and 2-3 of them are MC question. Re-take are available for both tests, and the system will take the highest score among three calculating methods as your final score:
-Score of first-take
-Average score
-80% of the second-take score

Test 1 covers topic 1-8, which is force and motion. The test is much easier than the assignment. Using the knowledge covered in DSE syllabus helps you to get a satisfactory score. Most of the questions are pretty straight forward solvable with simple equations e.g. mv^2/2=mgh or F=ma

Test 2 covers topic 9-15, which covers from rotation to simple harmonic motion. However, you can no longer abuse your knowledge acquired in secondary school to pass the test.

Final Exam consists of 45 MC questions and it is cumulative. However, there are questions from lecture 16-24 since it is not covered in the tests. Almost 15-20 questions are about thermodynamics.

The grading is okay but not good definitely. For your reference only,
Homework: 100/100 (mean:95.1)
Test 1: 7/10 (mean: 5.56, sd: 2.44)
Test 1 retake: 6/10 (mean: 5.5)
Test 2: 6/10 (mean: 5.18, sd: 2.59)
Test 2 retake: 7/10 (mean: 5.4)
Final exam: 31/45 (mean: 21.8, sd: 7.8)

Final grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very heavy as it covers many chapters in Physics. It is no longer a matter of putting some unknowns into a suitable equation and hence solve it. I took m1 and physics in HKDSE in got both 5* but it doesn't help me much in this course. At most of the time you are feeling hopeless that you can't even solve for one single question. And there's not much assistance provided except the help desk. The notes is shit and I was learning from the yahoo answer and wondering how the guy get the correct answer. But it takes you many time and eventually you are just memorising all the equations without knowing how to derive it and hope it will work in the examination.

However, if you know how to do the MasteringPhysics, then mostly you can get a B range in this course.

reviews.author: Vinca
reviews.title: Quite a difficult but useful course
reviews.comment_content:
It include many different topics. Most of them required you to use calculus to understand the  equations and answer the questions, like kinematics. The proof may also be useful as some questions in the exam may require you to do so, even if they are all in MC.

It also includes some basic vectors. Even if you have studied M2 before, you have to know how to apply it in Physics so it is not an easy stuff.

And as I have said, it include many different topics so you have to keep revising whenever one big topic is finished.

But overall, I believed these physics should be the basic things we have to learn. And I did learn something from it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
There were 4 lecturers in 17 fall. I attended all of the 4 (if lecture video also count <-- Leung Pak Wo).

And the one I was originally attending was Professor Altman lecture. Frankly speaking, quite boring. I understand his passion to make us feel the interest of physics, but the learning style of Hong Kong may not suit his teaching style. He wants an active learning environment that we can't give. So the lecture becomes a bit awkward, and boring when he always try to wake us up, but not teaching.

Then I sat Chen Tian Wen lecture. And I stayed for quite a long time. He explained everything so clearly and were very willing to answer our questions after class.

As Leung Pak Wo posted up his lecture video on Canvas, I also kind of "attended" his lesson. His explanation was also very clear like Chen Tian Wen. He also gave the answer to questions in the lecture notes while the others might not always do so. But from the lecture video, it is easy to see that he didn't allow anyone using phone or sleeping, which is sth you have to consider if you want to attend his lecture. XD

At last, just being curious, I sat in Cheung Man Fung lecture when we started the topic about heat and thermodynamics. He really explained them very clearly and his explanations and examples helped me a lot in this topic.

There were also 4 help desk sessions before the final exam and 3 of the lecturers (except Professor Altman) were there to answer your questions. That is very useful and I highly recommend you to go if you have any concept unclear.

To sum up, the 3 local lecturers are all very good and you can try by yourselves to find the one suitable for you. For me, I think it should be Cheung Man Fung.
reviews.comment_grading:
For your reference only,
Test1: 9/10 (mean: 5.56, SD: 2.44)
   Test 1 retake: 9/10 (mean: 5.5, SD not announced)
Test2: 9/10 (mean: 5.18, SD: 2.59)
   Test 2 retake: 7/10 (mean: 5.2, SD not announced)
Final exam: 38/45 (mean: 21.8, SD: 7.8)

Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to do a homework with around 8 questions every week. And they count into the final grade. Once you got wrong, you will lose 3% points from that question.

Well, for me, it was quite a pressure. But for some of the questions...actually most of them...you can go google...!?

(BTW, there are many supplementary questions for your revision. They do not count into any marks and you can try as many time as possible. They are very good practice and I have spent much time doing almost all of them. It did helped. It's not a must for you to do them, but practising will definitely help.)

reviews.author: Adrian Lai
reviews.title: Year 1 Course
reviews.comment_content:
This is a course for Engineering student admitted into first year and they require some preliminary understanding in Physics. Check the pre-requisite above for the course's requirements. The course syllabus is as follows:

- Physics quantity
- Newton's Law of Motion
- Work and Kinetic Energy
- Potential Energy and energy conversion
- Momentum, impulse and collision
- Dynamics of Rigid Bodies
- Angular Momentum
- Gravitation
- Periodic Motions
- Wave motions
- Thermal Properties
- Thermodynamics

If you have the textbook purchased, you will find that for the first few lectures, Dr. CHEN goes over a whole chapter in the book so the content itself might not be well covered. Purchasing the textbook is a must for online homework submission. I don't know much about the DSE syllabus but speaking from the IB graduate's point of view, a lot of the content here has already been slightly covered, especially the Dynamics of Rigid Bodies (Engineering - Option B). This course aims to show how a lot of the formulae in the topics are derived and used from Calculus so I personally don't find it hard to understand the calculus concepts in the course.

But, since there are a lot of concepts covered in the course, it might overwhelm you. Think twice before joining the course because there are lot more courses to choose from to satisfy the fundamental courses. I sometimes find it hard to understand the concept and use them efficiently in tests and homework.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. CHEN can sometimes be funny in the lectures. His teaching is clear and he often follows what is on the lecture notes. But, he always does a lot of proofs on the whiteboard and explain how such formula is derived. Although proofs are important for understanding, the final formula are always the ones to remember. There are always demonstrations at the end of the lecture and he's also keen to answer your questions after the lecture ends.
reviews.comment_grading:
Course assessment components:

- 10% Homework (MasteringPhysics)
- 20% First Test (Lectures 1 - 7)
- 20% Second Test (Lectures 8 - 15)
- 50% Final Exam
reviews.comment_workload: Every week, there is online homework assignment from MasteringPhysics. They are normally due on Sunday and you will be given approximately a week to finish it before the due date. The questions are sometimes hard and require more time to understand and finish. Apart form homework, it's also crucial to understand the lecture content in order to be able to score well in homework and mid-term exams (i.e. two tests). The textbook that we have purchased is somewhat useful when the lecture content is not well covered in the lecture notes.

reviews.author: Domenick
reviews.comment_content: Overall, the content was not too broad, and was as would be expected from an introductory Physics course. Although this course does include Calculus, approximately ten percent of questions include calculus, and usually for simple things such as determining acceleration given a velocity equation or for calculating power. Most of the course's difficulty lies in algebraic problems as they often require many more steps than the calculus based problems. The most difficult topics were most likely heat and it's transfer along with oscillations.
reviews.comment_teaching: The Teaching was very good, as my teacher spoke excellent English and worked through many problems and concepts on the whiteboard in each class session. The tutorials also proved quite helpful and were very important for understanding key concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not very lenient. The mean for quizzes is usually between 5 to 6 of 10, and the final had a mean of approximately 20 out of 80. I received approximately mean for the quizzes and final and received a B overall.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was perhaps a bit heavy, but overall not bad. If one stayed on top of their weekly homework sets, they would have no issue.

reviews.author: app_Sci
reviews.title: Take it in fall if you can. Spring is a disaster.
reviews.comment_content:
I was required to take this in spring as I need to have calculus background by taking math1012 in fall first.
IF YOU CAN TAKE IT IN FALL, TAKE IT IN FALL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
SPRING IS A DISASTER!!!!!!!!!!!
As the course contents was covered in most other reviews, I will not go in too much detail in this review.
Mechanics 65%, Waves 5%, Heat 30%.
There are 2 tests that use a computer to grade it.
Before the first test, it is mostly HKDSE stuff with some calculus (vector, differentiation, integration).
After first test, new stuff like dynamics of rigid body begin to emerge, angular momentum, etc.
It is suggested to preview the stuff as early as possible.
Thermodynamics will be another disaster.
Be sure to catch up the pace fast enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: SHENG Ping was actually just reading out loud from the lecture notes. Recommend CHEUNG Man Fung's lecture instead. His tutorials are good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Details for tests and HW are covered in other reviews. They're accurate and will thus be skipped.
Attendance was required for tutorials and these attendances (10 tutorials) counts for 5% of subject grade. (i.e. you get marks for just showing up, but if you are late for 15 mins, only 75% marks only, 30 mins, 50%, 45 mins, 25%, 1hr, none)
Grading scheme:
5% tutorial attendance
5% Mastering Physics Homework
20% Test 1
20% Test 2
50% Final exam
DO NOT BE FOOLED BY THE TESTS!!!!!! THE FINAL EXAM IS A WHOLE NEW LEVEL IN TERMS OF DIFFICULTY!!!!!!!

HW: Me:100/100. Mean: 86.1. SD: N/A
(It looks like they will round your MasteringPhysics HW scores. I only got 89.XX% in the MasteringPhysics. My masteringPhysics score multiplied by 10/9 gives about 99.6/100.)
Tutorials: 71.88%. Mean: around 80% SD: N/A
Test 1: Me: (6+10)/2=> 8/10. Mean and SD of first take: 5.2, ~3
Test 2: Me: (5+9)/2=> 7/10. Mean and SD of first take: 4.8, ~3
(PS: It is possible that Mean and SD will be changed after the retake)
Final exam: Me: 25/40. Mean and SD: 21.7, 8.5
Expected a B+-ish grade.
Got a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
(Almost) One mastering physics homework every week.
The questions in this homework is about the same difficulty as those in the tests. not very hard.
There will be extra exercise on mastering Physics that can help you with your test. Exam? Pray.

reviews.author: danny boy
reviews.title: You are going to be thrived for the final exam
reviews.comment_content:
Force and motion, Energy, Rigid body, Gravitation, Periodic motion, Wave, Thermodynamics.

If you have studied physics in secondary school, you will be familiar with more than half of the terms/topics in the course. And if you think you can skip half of the lectures and tutorials, you will be very sorry. The twist of physics with CALCULUS is a very big one. You may be able to get away with it in the first test, but you will be in deep trouble in the latter tests and exams. Make sure you do more questions and understand well about the physics with CALCULUS (well the physics part as well).

I give it an A as you can learn quite a lot of new things and topics in reasonable depth in the course. How much you can understand is another thing.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Really don't want to name anyone just guess. The lecturer pretty much copied from the notes, with some exceptionally advanced level proves, and explained with some heavily accented English which you will need some time to adapt to. If you are lucky to have choose his lectures, make sure you are well prepared before the lectures, or else you will not be able to understand a single thing in his class, and give up his lessons fairly easily and quickly like me.

Tutor is more easy to understand and teach you more practical skills to solve exam problems. Mr Jacky is a fairly hea but cheerful tutor who is always willing to help you in and after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Homework (raw score times some index >1)
20% Test 1
20% Test 2
50% Final
(Test score = [raw score out of 10] x [difficulty index of your paper (>=1)] ;
Test score is the average of the main and retest score only if you better your main test, otherwise only the main one counts)

80 sth should be enough for A range, depending on the overall results (and hence the difficulty of the paper).
Anything above 8 in the tests are pretty much a 10 after the adjustment, so don't waste your time for a retest.
As for exam :)  The prof announced midway into the exam, quoted "There are some hard questions in the paper. If you don't know how to do (dun un at all), don't waste time on them. We will find a way to adjust the score. WE WILL GIVE YOU 10 MORE MINUTES, OKAY?" It was at this moment, everyone knew, we ______ up. Good thing is 60% in 45 MC is enough for A range, not like some course you still get a B for mid 90s. And my advice is do not lose interest and focus because of the hard questions, do not give up till the last minute, hard work can sometimes conspire miracle. :)
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework: masteringPhysics, 1 per week, 7-10 questions per assignments, ~10 in the semester.
It is not light but I think it is fairly standard for a science course (just see someone's review on a MATH1000~ course and the workload comment is "WEBWORK WEBWORK WEBWORK ..."
And it pretty much tells you which question it is from in the textbook (with different values of course), so if you can get a the correct answer for the textbook questions (odd no. ans provided in book) you will know how to do. (and I think the tutor is willing to help you out)
p.s. Buying a NEW textbook for a new account for masteringPhysics is a must, you are going to get away with it with a second hand one.

Tests: In early Oct and Nov, with retests available a week after each one, 10 questions in 65~75 min (i dun rmb)
So if you are not a perfectionist, masochist, optimist, or more likely an ill-prepared one, I strongly advice you not to take both retests. Who wants to take four tests in two months when you can get away with two! So be well prepared for the tests.

Main part: Do questions after each chapter in the textbook, depending on your time available and what grade you want to have. You do not need to worry about not enough questions, there are like 100 of them per chapter (2000 in total). Do them according to your interest and ability. For me, I have not done any and I am very much prepared and accepted the consequences

(btw I don't really know what grade should I give for workload. I will give a B for my personal experience for not doing any extra questions)

reviews.author: Alpha703
reviews.title: Dr. Cheung is suitable for anyone who want to major in PHYS
reviews.comment_content:
Summarized below:
Physical quantities, vectors, 2D motions, Newton's Laws(3 laws, relative motion, reference frame, friction, circular motion) Energy(Work, Kinetic, Potential, conservation), Momentum(Collisions, Impulse, conservation, center of mass), Dynamics of rigid bodies(Moment of inertia, rotation KE, angular motions, torque, angular momentum), Gravitation(Gravitational force and PE, planetary motions, spherical mass distribution, apparent weight), Periodic motion(Simple harmonic motion, pendulums, damped and forced oscillations, resonance), Wave motion(Mathematics, power, reflection, standing wave, sound, Doppler effect), Temperature and heat(Thermal expansion, heat capacity, latent heat, heat transfer), Kinetic Theory, Thermodynamics(1st and 2nd law, heat engines, type of thermodynamic processes, thermodynamic properties of ideal gas, entropy)

Tutorial sessions are about doing practice problems in small groups, including 'warm-up exercises', 'basic practice' and 'context-rich problems'.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Cheung clearly shows his passion on teaching. He does almost all proofs of the theorems/formulas patiently and clearly, then address them with more daily-life examples, allow us to understand even more mathematically complex concepts. He is also willing to discuss physics concepts with us after lectures, no matter are they out of syllabus or not. Of course, his proofs are not very useful in doing homework and exam questions, but it's still worth to learn them as the brush up/tidy up your physics concepts. Students who want to major PHYS must not miss his lectures and proofs.

Dr. Ko is the tutor in tutorial sessions. He can guide us to the right path to solve the physics problems in tutorials without telling us the exact answer/steps skillfully.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
Assignments 5% Tutorials 5% Test 1 20% Test 2 20% Final Exam 50%
Grading is fair.
Assignments 10/10 (Mean: 9)
Tutorials(Attendance) 13/14 (Mean: 13.2)
Test 1 8.65/10 (Mean 7.1)
Test 2 10/10 (Mean 6.2)
Final exam 31/45 (Mean 24.7) --> A-
Important notes:
-There are 're-takes' for the two tests. If your re-take score is higher than first-take, the raw score will be obtained from the average of the two 'takes'. Otherwise, only score from first-take is calculated. You will never suffer by attending 're-takes' of the tests.
-The raw scores obtained directly in tests and final exams will be adjusted based on the difficulties of the problem sets to become your final scores(that is used to calculate the grade)
-Each tutorial attendance counts for 2 marks(7 tutorials counted-->14 marks). 15 minute late-->-0.5 marks  30 min-->-1  45 min--> -1.5  Don't attend--> -2(0 mark)
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable workload.
Assignments: 1 per week, each consists of 6-9 questions, basically all answers of them can be obtained by Google. They are done in intranet provided by MasteringPhysics, which mean you must buy the MasteringPhysics textbook to do them. Attempts are limited, and wrong attempts will result in marks deduction, which is different from WebWork in mathematics.
Attendance: Only taken in tutorials. Refer to 'grading' part for details.
Tests: You need to 'enroll' in the test time-slots by yourself(or else 0 marks). Each consists of 10 MCs/SQs, and you have 65 minutes. They are done in computers in room 4382 instead of conventional papers. Difficulty is usually standard. There are reviews(just like paper-checking) and re-takes, also need to enroll in time-slots by yourself.
Final exam: 45 MCs. Done in 3 hours on paper(not computer in tests). Half of the questions are very hard, so good luck on that.

reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty good
The midterm is split into 2 tests at around 1/3 and 2/3 of the semester, each for 15%, allow retake which means you can take it a second attempt, if 2nd attempt > 1st attempt, score = (2nd+1st)/2, if 2nd<1st, 2nd score is omitted.

Overall:

I got 14/15 for 1st test and 11/15 for 2nd test, 36/45 for final, overall A+
All of my highschool friends got A range (A+ x1, A x2, A- x1)
